properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow and very strong winds on Friday... Snow at times heavy combined with northeast winds gusting to over 70 kilometres per hour will affect the Lower North Shore beginning early Friday morning. Quickly accumulating snow and reduced visibilities could make travel difficult. A period of rain will be possible in Blanc-Sablon Friday evening. Conditions should improve early Saturday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T00:21:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T08:22:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4168032315.2020
Area: Chevery, Blanc-Sablon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system from Quebec will move through the Davis Straight tonight. Very strong northeast winds with gusts to 100 km/h are expected late this afternoon and early this evening. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-27T00:17:57-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly near 100 km/h Friday night. Locations: Postville-Makkovik to Hopedale. Time span: Friday night and Saturday. Remarks: Snow will develop near noon on Friday, becoming heavy at times Friday night. The snow will combine with strong northerly winds Friday night and Saturday to reduce visibility in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve Saturday night as the snow tapers off and the winds ease. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T00:27:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T08:28:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3495669241.2020
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will produce strong easterly winds in Grise Fiord on Friday. Wind gusts up to 80 km/h will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow. Due to the uncertainty in the strength of the system at this time, the severity of the blowing snow conditions is still unknown. Watch for updated alerts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northerly up to 60 km/h. Locations: Halifax county- east of Porters Lake and Pictou county. Time span: beginning near noon until Friday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin near noon then transition to a mix of ice pellets and snow this evening with a risk of freezing rain. Areas along the Atlantic coast may see a switch over to rain briefly late this afternoon. Precipitation will taper off Friday morning. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and rain expected Thursday night and Friday. Maximum snowfall: near 15 cm possible for parts of southern, central and northern Newfoundland. Maximum rainfall: 30 to 50 mm possible, most likely somewhere along the south coast. Strongest winds: southeasterly 80 to 100 km/h followed by southwesterlies near 80 km/h. Time span: Thursday night, Friday, Friday night and likely Saturday for the west and north. Remarks: A low pressure system will approach Newfoundland from the south on Thursday and track through western or central regions of the Island. Snow will begin Thursday evening in the south and spread elsewhere throughout the night. Precipitation will likely change over to rain for southern areas overnight Thursday night and elsewhere on Friday. Precipitation may change back to snow along the west coast and over the Great Northern Peninsula on Friday night while elsewhere conditions will taper off. Snow will eventually taper off to flurries in the west and north by Saturday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-26T17:22:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T01:23:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2795904735.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Freezing rain: 2 to 5 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 70 km/h. Les Suetes winds up to 80 km/h. Locations: eastern Nova Scotia, including Cape Breton. Time span: this afternoon until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Snow will begin this afternoon then transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain in the evening and overnight. Freezing rain is expected to change over to rain mainly over Sydney Metro and Cape Breton county before switching back to snow Friday afternoon. Flurries will persist Friday afternoon and combine with strong northwesterly winds which could give reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow. Flurries will taper off Saturday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-26T23:55:34-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A snowstorm is expected Friday and Saturday. Maximum snowfall: 15 to 30 cm possible in the southeast, central and along the mid coast. Maximum rainfall: 10 to 15 mm possible over southeastern Labrador. Strongest winds: northerly near 80 km/h. Time span: Friday morning to Saturday evening. Remarks: Snow will begin Friday morning in southeastern Labrador and will spread elsewhere throughout the day. Precipitation will likely change over to rain for southeastern areas on Friday night, with snow persisting elsewhere. Strong northerly winds will develop behind the system on Friday night and will persist over most areas on Saturday. These winds will combine with fresh snow to cause significantly reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve by Saturday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-27T00:27:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T08:28:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1377194834.2020

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Telephone Service Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: Telus has informed Clearwater County of an outage that is impacting the ability of TELUS MOBILE CUSTOMERS to contact 9-1-1. This outage is impacting TELUS MOBILITY CUSTOMERS across the province. These customers will not be able to dial 9-1-1 form anywhere in Alberta at this time. If you require emergency assistance from police, fire, or ambulance, use a landline or alternate cellular carrier. ### This outage DOES NOT impact landlines. Landlines can still be used to call 9-1-1 in an emergency. This outage is only impacting TELUS MOBILITY customers. It does not impact other providers. Telus is working to resolve this issue as quickly as possible.
Expires: 2020-04-01T11:26:09-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Clearwater County, 2020-03-25T11:23:51-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-6271
Area: Clearwater County
properties.Author: Clearwater County

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm, except as high as 50 mm for the Burin and Connaigre Peninsulas. Locations: the Avalon, Burin, Connaigre, and Bonavista Peninsulas, as well as Clarenville and Terra Nova. Time span: overnight tonight until Friday evening. Remarks: Snow will develop tonight before changing to rain by Friday morning. The rain will be accompanied by mild temperatures and strong easterly winds, resulting in significant snow melt. As a result, localized flooding is likely. The public is therefore advised to clear storm drains of ice and snow where possible ahead of the rain. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-26T23:50:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T07:51:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0305179162.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed precipitation expected for Thursday into Friday. Total snowfall: 5 to 20 cm. 30 cm or more possible over the Cape Breton Highlands. Freezing rain: 2 to 5 mm possible. Maximum wind gusts: northeasterly up to 70 km/h. Les Suetes winds up to 80 km/h. Locations: central and eastern Nova Scotia, including Cape Breton. Time span: Thursday afternoon until Friday afternoon. Remarks: Precipitation is expected to begin as heavy wet snow Thursday morning then transition to a mix of ice pellets or freezing rain in the evening and overnight. Freezing rain may create hazardous conditions over Cape Breton Thursday night into Friday morning. On Friday the area of precipitation will have moved out of the province, however strong northwesterly winds in flurries will likely persist in onshore winds from the Gulf of Saint Lawrence giving reduced visibilities in snow and blowing snow. The highest total snowfall accumulations are expected over the Cape Breton Highlands. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-26T17:22:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-26T01:23:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3576582909.2020
